form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Brown (for himself, Mr. Barrasso, Mr. Wicker, Mr. Coons, Mr. Bennet, Mr. Whitehouse, Mrs. Feinstein, Mr. Pryor, and Ms. Warren) submitted the following resolution; which was considered and agreed to

form.official-title: Designating February 28, 2014, as Rare Disease Day.

whereas.text: Whereas a rare disease or disorder is one that affects a small number of patients – in the United States, typically less than 200,000 individuals annually;
Whereas as of the date of approval of this resolution, nearly 7,000 rare diseases affect approximately 30,000,000 people in the United States and their families;
Whereas children with rare genetic diseases account for more than half of the population affected by rare diseases in the United States;
Whereas many rare diseases are serious, life-threatening, and lack an effective treatment;

Whereas the Food and Drug Administration has made great strides in involving the patient in the drug review process as part of its Patient-Focused Drug Development program, an initiative that originated in the Food and Drug Administration Safety and Innovation Act ( Public Law 112–144 );
Whereas a third of all treatments approved by the Food and Drug Administration in 2013 were orphan products intended to treat rare diseases;

Whereas rare diseases and conditions include epidermolysis bullosa, progeria, sickle cell anemia, spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), Tay-Sachs, cystic fibrosis, pulmonary fibrosis, many childhood cancers, and fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva;
Whereas 2013 marked the 30th anniversary of the Orphan Drug Act and the National Organization for Rare Disorders;
Whereas the National Organization for Rare Disorders sponsors Rare Disease Day in the United States to increase public awareness of rare diseases;
Whereas Rare Disease Day is observed each year on the last day of February;
Whereas Rare Disease Day is a global event, first observed in the United States on February 28, 2009, and observed in 60 countries in 2013; and
Whereas Rare Disease Day is expected to be observed globally for years to come, providing hope and information for rare disease patients around the world: Now, therefore, be it

paragraph.text: designates February 28, 2014, as Rare Disease Day;
recognizes the importance of improving awareness and encouraging accurate and early diagnosis of rare diseases and disorders; and
supports a national and global commitment to improving access to, and developing new treatments, diagnostics, and cures for rare diseases and disorders.
